newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: EU foreign ministers endorse leg-hold traps deals.
newsitem.headline: EU foreign ministers endorse leg-hold traps deals.

text.p: European Union foreign ministers endorsed on Monday draft deals struck between the European Commission and Canada and Russia on more humane standards for traps used to catch animals for their fur.

"The Council (of EU foreigh ministers) was pleased with the progress made in these negotiations," it said in a statement, pointing to improvements compared with earlier deals rejected as too weak by EU environment ministers, who will have final say on June 19-20.
The ministers urged the EU executive, which will now work to finalise the two deals, to push on with talks with the United States, with whom talks are stalled, and report back quickly.

In the revised deal, Canada has accepted a ban, effective immediately the agreement comes into force, on all types of jaw-type, leghold traps for seven of 12 Canadian species under consideration, EU diplomats said on Friday.
Use of such traps for the remaining five species will be outlawed from March 31, 2000 provided the deal is in place before October 1 this year.
Russia will ban the traps by December 31, 1999 "if adequate financial assistance is provided to replace existing traps".
If not, the traps will be phased out at the latest four years after the agreement comes into force.
The revised text also removes any derogation from the ban for trappers among Canada's indigenous populations and limits Russia's derogation to the use of a traditional wooden trap.

Difficulties remain in the way of an EU trapping deal with the United States, which considers it too strict, and where questions remain about the division of powers between federal and state authorities to negotiate on trapping.
